quote: Strip a proud nobility of their bloated estates, reduce them to a level with plain republicans, send them forth to labor and teach their children to enter the workshops or handle the plow, and you will thus humble the proud traitors.
context: Advocating for confiscation and redistribution of Confederate land
significance: Stevens demanded accountability: land confiscation, treason trials, economic justice. He was ignored. We're still paying the price.

quote: I repose in this quiet and secluded spot, not from any natural preference for solitude, but finding other cemeteries limited as to race by charter rules, I have chosen this that I might illustrate in my death the principles which I advocated through a long life: Equality of Man before his Creator.
context: Stevens was buried in a Black cemetery because white cemeteries were segregated
source: Epitaph at Shreiner-Concord Cemetery, Lancaster, PA
significance: Even in death, Stevens made a statement. He lived his principles when others abandoned them.

quote: This is a country for white men, and by God, as long as I am President, it shall be a government for white men.
context: Letter to Missouri Governor Thomas Fletcher
source: Andrew Johnson Papers, Library of Congress
significance: Lincoln's successor explicitly stating his white supremacist governing philosophy

quote: The attempt to place the white population under the domination of persons of color in the South has impaired, if not destroyed, the kindly relations that had previously existed between them.
context: Third Annual Message to Congress, defending his obstruction of Reconstruction
significance: Johnson blaming Reconstruction for racial tensions rather than slavery and the Confederacy

quote: P emphasized that you have to face the fact that the whole problem is really the blacks. The key is to devise a system that recognizes this while not appearing to.
context: From Haldeman's diary, referring to President Nixon
significance: Nixon's own Chief of Staff documenting the President's explicit racial strategy

quote: The more Negroes who register as Democrats in the South, the sooner the Negrophobe whites will quit the Democrats and become Republicans. That's where the votes are.
source: New York Times, May 17, 1970 (via 'The Emerging Republican Majority')
significance: The architect of the Southern Strategy explaining the racial math openly

quote: You start out in 1954 by saying 'N----r, n----r, n----r.' By 1968 you can't say 'n----r' - that hurts you, backfires. So you say stuff like 'forced busing,' 'states' rights,' and all that stuff... You're getting so abstract now, you're talking about cutting taxes, and all these things you're talking about are totally economic things and a byproduct of them is, blacks get hurt worse than whites.
context: Interview with political scientist Alexander Lamis, published 1990
significance: GOP strategist explicitly explaining how racist appeals became coded over time
warningText: Contains a racial slur (partially censored). Atwater used this language to explain how explicit racism evolved into coded messaging.

quote: Some Republicans gave up on winning the African American vote, looking the other way or trying to benefit politically from racial polarization. I am here today as the Republican chairman to tell you we were wrong.
significance: Official Republican Party apology acknowledging the Southern Strategy
